title: BUSINESS OPINION: "PM turned us into laughing stock of Europe" | Leicester Mercury
text:
Uncertainty, uncertainty, uncertainty - If there's one thing business leaders have been saying these past few years, it's that they hate uncertainty, writes business editor Tom Pegden. 
The uncertainty that came about in the run-up to, during and after the credit crunch. 
The uncertainty immediately following the 2010 General Election, when the Tories had to get into bed with the Lib Dems. 
The uncertainty in David Cameron which led him to offer an in-out referendum to try to keep the support of anti-EU MPs and Tory voters tempted by UKIP. 
Then there was the uncertainty that followed the Brexit vote itself, and the bullish – some might say gung-ho – way the Government pursued its policy of preparing to pull out. 
All that followed by the uncertainty of Mr Cameron bailing out on the mess he'd caused – and retiring to his £25,000 garden shed. 
If only we could all do that. 
And now this. A British Prime Minister in the form of Theresa May, sitting on a perfectly workable parliamentary majority and throwing it all away in a General Election result that provided the complete opposite of the "strong and stable" Government she kept parroting on about. 
Read more: Transgender Labour election candidate attacks Tories over DUP deal 
What an absolute embarrassment. She even helped make Jeremy Corbyn look like leadership material. 
She's turned us into the laughing stock of Europe.And worse than that, she has threatened the stability of the whole country. 
How on earth are we supposed to reassure the world's banks, global manufacturers and other big businesses based here, for instance, that – come our split from the union – that they will be better off based here than in Frankfurt, Paris, or northern Italy? 
This Government failed to win the mandate it needed for Brexit, for increasing levies on firms employing EU workers, or even for simplifying the tax system. 
It couldn't have got things more wrong. 
It would be funny if it wasn't so terrifying. Business leaders must be wondering what bombshell is going to drop next. 
About a year ago a Leicestershire accountant told me business has had to get used to living in a semi-permanent state of uncertainty. 
One's thing's for certain, Theresa May must go.
